trial_identification.studytitle: The Epi-No trial: Effect of intravaginal balloon device on levator trauma in mothers following childbirth
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Epi-No Study: Effect of antenatal intravaginal balloon device on levator trauma in mothers following childbirth

interventions.interventions: Use of intravaginal balloon device to distend pelvic floor muscle and reduce likelihood of traumas at childbirth, from 37 weeks' gestation to delivery. The patient inserts the device vaginally and inflates it intermittently, several times a day, to dilate the birth canal.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Levator trauma as assessed by translabial ultrasound

secondaryOutcome.outcome: >20% increase in hiatal dimensions at rest as assessed by translabial ultrasound
>20% increase in hiatal dimensions on Valsalva as assessed by translabial ultrasound

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: First pregnancy progressing beyond 20 weeks, singleton, cephalic, no contraindications to normal vaginal delivery.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Complications requiring planned Caesarean Section, multiple pregnancy, malpresentation, previous pregnancies beyond 20 weeks' gestation

trial_design.concealment: Participants identified through Antenatal Clinics at Nepean Hospital and Royal Prince Alfred (RPA) Hospital. Allocation at time of recruitment through phone call to third party who holds a computer-generated randomisation list concealed from researchers.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Nepean Hospital Derby St Penrith 2750 NSW

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The EpiNo trial is trialing the use of a commercially available intravaginal balloon device in order to determine whether this device reduces the risk of major pelvic floor trauma at vaginal delivery.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Sydney West Area Health Service Human Research Ethics Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Nepean Hospital Derby St Penrith 2750 NSW

contact.name: Prof. Hans Peter Dietz
